title: Vaccines, Combos: Drug Class, Uses, Side Effects, Drug Names
author: Medical Reviewer Sarfaroj Khan; BHMS; PGD Health Operations
description: Combo vaccines are combinations of two or more vaccines. Learn about how they work, usages, side effects, and a list of drugs.
cleaned_text: How do combo vaccines work? Combo [vaccines](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccines/definition.htm) are combinations of two or more vaccines. Vaccines are biologic products that provide protection against infectious diseases. Routine [childhood](https://www.rxlist.com/childhood/definition.htm) [immunization](https://www.rxlist.com/immunization/definition.htm) with vaccines has reduced the [incidence](https://www.rxlist.com/incidence/definition.htm) of many deadly infectious diseases that were common and caused considerable [morbidity](https://www.rxlist.com/morbidity/definition.htm) and [mortality](https://www.rxlist.com/mortality/definition.htm) [in](https://www.rxlist.com/in/definition.htm) the past. Vaccines work by stimulating the body's [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_system/definition.htm) to produce antibodies against specific [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/disease/definition.htm)-causing organisms, and protect a person from becoming infected when exposed to these germs. The main component of vaccines is the [antigen](https://www.rxlist.com/antigen/definition.htm) from specific organisms that generate [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/immune/definition.htm) responses to the particular organisms. Vaccines are purified preparations from weakened or inactivated organisms, the [proteins](https://www.rxlist.com/proteins/definition.htm) or toxins they produce, or from fragments of [genetic](https://www.rxlist.com/genetic/definition.htm) material. Some vaccines are synthetically produced to resemble disease-causing pathogens. Vaccines also contain substances that preserve and stabilize the vaccine and boost [immune response](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_response/definition.htm). Combo vaccines provide [immunity](https://www.rxlist.com/immunity/definition.htm) against two or more of the following diseases: [Diphtheria](https://www.rxlist.com/diphtheria/definition.htm), caused by vaccines by the [FDA](https://www.rxlist.com/fda/definition.htm) for use in the USA include: - Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids (bacterial toxins chemically altered to remove their [toxicity](https://www.rxlist.com/toxicity/definition.htm)) - Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and [acellular](https://www.rxlist.com/acellular/definition.htm)pertussis vaccine - Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, inactivated poliovirus, and [Haemophilus pertussis, inactivated poliovirus, [hepatitis poliovirus, [hepatitis](https://www.rxlist.com/hepatitis/definition.htm)B, and Haemophilus and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis, inactivated poliovirus vaccine - Hepatitis B and Haemophilus influenzae type B vaccine - Tetanus and reduced diphtheria toxoids and acellular pertussis vaccine How are combo vaccines used? Combo vaccines are administered as [intramuscular](https://www.rxlist.com/intramuscular_im/definition.htm) injections in a series of doses on a prescribed schedule, mostly as routine immunization in children and adolescents. Adults who have not received [primary](https://www.rxlist.com/primary/definition.htm) immunization in childhood may be administered tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccines. Combo vaccines are approved by the FDA for use in: Children and adolescents - Primary and booster immunization against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and hepatitis [B virus](https://www.rxlist.com/b_virus/definition.htm)infections [Prophylaxis](https://www.rxlist.com/prophylaxis/definition.htm)after exposure to diphtheria - Tetanus and diphtheria prophylaxis in wound management - Catch-up [vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccination/definition.htm)for children and adolescents, who were not fully immunized before age 7 against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis - Immunization during [pregnancy](https://www.rxlist.com/pregnancy/definition.htm)in adolescents against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis Adults - Primary and booster immunization against diphtheria and tetanus - Prophylaxis after exposure to diphtheria - Tetanus and diphtheria prophylaxis in wound management - Booster immunization against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis - Immunization during pregnancy against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis What are side effects of combo vaccines? Side effects of combo vaccines may include the following: - Injection site reactions include: [Erythema](https://www.rxlist.com/erythema/definition.htm)(redness) - Swelling [Pain](https://www.rxlist.com/pain/definition.htm)and soreness - Tenderness and warmth Mass and fussiness - Restlessness [Somnolence](https://www.rxlist.com/somnolence/definition.htm)(drowsiness) - Decreased consciousness - Decreased appetite of - Erythematous rash (rash with redness of the [skin](https://www.rxlist.com/skin/definition.htm)) - Maculopapular rash (flat lesions with [Angioedema](https://www.rxlist.com/angioedema/definition.htm)(swelling in the tissue under the skin or [mucous](https://www.rxlist.com/mucous/definition.htm)membranes) - Face edema pain a group of nerves shoulders, and hands) count](https://www.rxlist.com/platelet_count/definition.htm)in the blood) Information contained herein is not intended to cover all possible side effects, precautions, warnings, drug interactions, allergic reactions, or adverse effects. Check with your [doctor](https://www.rxlist.com/doctor/definition.htm) or [pharmacist](https://www.rxlist.com/pharmacist/definition.htm) to make sure these drugs do not cause any harm when you take them along with other medicines. Never stop taking your [medication](https://www.rxlist.com/medication/definition.htm) and never change your dose or frequency without consulting your doctor. What are names of combo vaccines?
